The Schlieffen Plan was a plan made by a top German general before the start of WW1. The Schlieffen Plan was a tactic that would make it so that Germany wouldn't have to fight a war on two fronts in the west against France and the in the east against Russia. The plan was the idea that the Germans would knock France out of the war in 6 weeks by capturing Paris. The Germans then thought that it would take 6 weeks for Russia to mobilize its army to the eastern front. Within those 6 weeks the German army would knock France out of the war then transport its entire army to the eastern front. This of course did not happen. The Schlieffen Plan was doomed to fail. It counted on luck and luck only.
